What a crazy crazy year

After some poor trading in 2022, Iâ€™d ran my portfolio down to 4 figs which is where I started the year and I would not have believed you if you told me Iâ€™d finish the year on 6 figs.

Especially after Iâ€™d reached 6 figs in July and lost it all back down to low 5 figs by end of August

Whats more valuable than the money Iâ€™ve made this year is the friends Iâ€™ve made along the way, and the lessons Iâ€™ve learnt from running up, nearly losing it all and then running up again. I keep a trading journal of my trades and no Iâ€™m not going to sit here and list my winners, instead Iâ€™m going to mostly talk about my mistakes as this is where Iâ€™ve learnt the most valuable lessons and Iâ€™d love to share these with you all in the hope that you too can learn from my mistakes:

1) Sizing

Sizing is so so important. The main reason Iâ€™d ran my port down twice is from poor sizing. I like to be aggressive with my trading style and my allocations but Iâ€™ve learnt to set myself limits. I was putting in 30-40% of my port on shitcoins and new launches (hello $bald lol) which repeatedly cost me. My new system with my port larger is now as following:

10-20% allocation per play depending on how early I think I am, and how high my conviction is. You want to make sure youâ€™re maximising your winners. For shitcoins/memes my limit is now 1% but in general since evaluating my journal Iâ€™ve tended to trade these less and less (see below). This is a system Iâ€™ve set as my port has grown. If you want to build quick with a smaller port then Iâ€™d split your port into 2-4 plays and then spread your risk more once youâ€™ve grown your port more.

Correct sizing also means you donâ€™t over react to red candles. This is a sign I use for myself to decide whether Iâ€™ve over allocated. If youâ€™ve over allocated to a play you will panic/worry/stress when it pulls backs, whereas if youâ€™ve sized well youâ€™re far less reactive. Correct sizing leads to better control of emotions.

2) 8 plays accounted for 70% of my profits.

This showed me that I only need a few good trades throughout the year and donâ€™t need to be constantly looking for new trades. In fact it's clear from my journal that over trading was a big profit killer for me. This also ties into sizing, unless Iâ€™m happy to put 10% of my portfolio into a play I tend to stay out (shitcoins aside) and this helps in limiting how many trades I take. Additionally I tended to perform better when I had around 6-8 plays in my port, which makes sense given I was able to keep up with all of them easier.

3) I entered a lot of losing trades straight after closing winning trades

This is something I noticed about halfway through the year; spurned on by the adrenaline of winning trades I would always look for a new trade for my next dopamine hit as soon as Iâ€™d closed the winning trade. This led to many rushed trades without thorough thinking and giving back profits fresh from a winning trade. Interestingly this is something I did far more than when Iâ€™d lost trades (I guess I was more aware of not chasing losses).

Whenever I close a trade now (winning or losing) I wait at least a few hours before entering a new trade just to make sure Iâ€™m thinking clearly and my judgment is unaffected by the emotions of a win or loss.

4) Ignore previous price action

Iâ€™m not saying enter a trade after itâ€™s done a 10x in one hour but instead what I mean is to make your decision on entering a trade based on where the price can go, as opposed to what the price has done so far. Earlier in the year I ignored some plays because theyâ€™ve already done a 2x and went onto lose out much much more. Imagine if we did this for $mubi $rlb or $unibot for example. Itâ€™s much better to decide where you think the price can go and see how far the play is from that price as opposed to worrying youâ€™re late and the opportunity has gone just because the price has already moved. Similar to this, if you think a coin can do a 5x, then don't fade it if it's moved 10-20%. 

5) Adjust your risk based on market conditions

I donâ€™t try and guess where btc is going to go and sell at the opportune moment to then buy back 10-20% lower. Looking back however I think itâ€™s important to at least adjust your risk/sizing based on market conditions. I should also have adjusted my targets. In poorer conditions you should lower your targets for exits in trades. For example from Jan-June and October-Dec we had really nice runs in the market whereas July-September was tougher. I lost a lot of capital in July-Sep as I was forcing trades and sizing as I was in the favourable conditions of the first half of the year. In hindsight I should have reduced my sizing and traded less when the market was tougher. I was too greedy and impatient.

Wait for good market conditions, donâ€™t force it in tougher conditions. Adjust your sizing/targets based on the market conditions.

6) New launches and shitcoins

These are the type of plays where I lost the most money. Yes ofc there is big gains to be made here too but personally this is not my edge and it became clear after a while that my success rate from these is poor. Allocate accordingly and limit how many of these type of trades you're taking, especially if you're newer to the game. Definitely an area for me to improve on in 2024. 

7) â€˜Psychological comfortâ€™ is an understated factor

I suppose this goes back to allocation and sizing again. When I had a smaller port I felt more comfortable being 100% allocated to active plays. As my port has grown however I've become more uncomfortable having 100% of my port in active positions. This is something well explained by @0x_Kun. The first time I ran my port to 6 figs I remained in nearly 100% active positions and this was psychologically uncomfortable. This led to me worrying more over fluctuations in my port and making some poor decisions as a result. What I like to do now is supply lp in tokenless projects with around 10-20% of my port. This creates a â€˜floorâ€™ for my port which I find more psychologically comfortable and results in me reacting less to price movements. Everyone will have a different tolerance to what % of their port theyâ€™re happy to have in active positions but my point here is to try and find that sweet spot for yourself as itâ€™ll allow you to remain calmer during pullbacks.

8) Keep a trading journal

Tbh I feel a lot of the points Iâ€™ve made are nothing new and youâ€™re likely aware of most already but having my journal and having a record of all my mistakes really drummed them all home for me. Iâ€™m a firm believer that we learn best from mistakes and the journal has been pivotal in this for me. Donâ€™t be afraid of losing money, itâ€™s part of the process.

9) Keeping your money is the most difficult skill to master

I've already learnt this the hard way twice over. I truly believe crypto is a gift for making life changing money for us all, and if you work hard and put the hours in you can make money from this, but the real trick is learning to keep it. This is part of the reason I like to set a 'floor' in my port too, and I've learnt to take profits to fiat once  in a while also. Whatever you do, make sure you have some sort of end plan, and be very protective over your money once you've made it. Don't suddenly start aping into anything that comes around.

10) Your network is the most valuable asset in this space

Lastly it only feels right to give credit to the people whoâ€™ve really helped me on this journey and to those who Iâ€™ve learned so much from. Iâ€™m under no illusions that I wouldnâ€™t have achieved anywhere near what I have without those around me:

Nullity User Data Report

Incentivized Testnet and Avalanche Mainnet

- Incentivized Testnet Participant Addresses: 2,425
- Avalanche Mainnet Participant Addresses: 5,155 (excluding anomalous TXs)
- Addresses that participated in both the testnet and mainnet: 550

Avalanche Mainnet Detailed User Data

- Total TXs: 119,045 (excluding anomalous TXs)
- Total Mints: 265,498
- Total Winning Tickets: 34,942
- Average Winning Rate: 34,942 / 265,498 * 100% = 13.161%
- Lucky Tickets: 2,767
- Lucky Ticket Appearance Rate: 2,7
67 / 34,942 * 100% = 7.912%

Value Calculation

- Total Mint Value: 265,498 mints * 0.1AVAX/mint = 26,549.8AVAX
- Value per Winning Ticket: 26,549.8 AVAX/ 34,942 = 0.75982485AVAX
- AMM Pool Allocation: 50% * 26,549.8 AVAX/0.75982485AVAX = 17,471*10,000

NULL Tokenomics:

- Total Supply: 720,000,000 NULL = 72,000 * 10,000 tickets
- Airdrop Amount: 1% of total supply = 720 * 10,000
- Treasury Balance: 72,000 * 10,000 - 34,942 * 10,000 - 720 * 10,000 - 17,471 * 10,000 = 18,867 * 10,000
- Circulating Supply: Total supply - treasury balance = 72,000 * 10,000 - 18,867 * 10,000 = 53,133*10,000

Key Takeaways

The Nullity community has grown significantly since the incentivized testnet.
The average winning rate on the Avalanche mainnet is 13.161%.
The lucky ticket appearance rate is 7.912%.
The AMM pool will be allocated 17,471 tickets.
The total supply of $NULL is 720,000,000.
The airdrop amount is 7,200,000.
The treasury balance is 18,867,000.
The circulating supply is 53,133,000.

Nullity Data Statistics Error Announcement

We at Nullity have discovered two data statistics errors that may impact the winning results of some users. We sincerely apologize to all affected users.

   - When a user submits X transactions in the same block, and the user wins Y prizes (1-6) in that block, the correct statistical data should be Y. However, we incorrectly calculated it as X*Y. This will impact the total number of prizes won by the user.

  - When a user submits X transactions in the same block, the correct statistical data should be X. However, we incorrectly assumed that each user only submits one transaction in the same block. This will impact the statistical data for Total Mint.

These errors occurred because we initially assumed that users would only submit one transaction per block when using Metamask to mint tickets. However, we did not consider the possibility that users could submit multiple transactions in the same block by calling the contract.

We will airdrop compensation to all affected users.

We will update the website data as soon as possible.

We at Nullity are committed to providing a fair and transparent platform for all users. We will continue to work hard to improve our service quality and ensure that user rights are protected.

Nullity Team

gm, $NULL community!

In addition, we will open-source the FutureHash core code after $NULL officially adds the AMM pool.

This will help users understand how Nullity uses the FutureHash Lottery Protocol to determine if a user has won. 

We will also write relevant documentation to help community members understand the protocol.

Thursday, December 28, 2023 (EST)

Dear Nullity Community,

Thank you for being patience and understanding.

It has been our second 24-hour workday since the start of the Nullity testnet event.

The calculation of correct data is still ongoing.  However, our calculation is nearing completion. In order to ensure the accuracy of the users, we need to conduct a secondary data comparison and a third random sampling comparison. Once confirmed, we will update the Nullity website data.

In the meantime:

Once we have completed the data validation, we will announce the update information on the official website. Users can view the correct winning information on the Nullity website and claim $NULL tokens.

We are committed to providing a fair and just outcome for all Nullity supporters. We will continue to keep you updated on our progress.

Thank you again for your support.

The Nullity Team

We have discovered nearly 20,000 anomalous TXs in nearly 5,000 blocks. After investigation, we found that around 100 users were responsible for these malicious TXs. 

- Most of our users are our true supporters. 

We have successfully cleaned up these abnormal transactions and expect the recalculation work to be completed within 24 hours. 

Once the recalculation is complete, you can check your updated winning results on the our website.

We are committed to providing a fair and transparent platform for all Nullity supporters. Please believe that we will do our utmost to resolve this incident and maintain the trust of the community.

One might inquire about the feasibility of minting inscriptions utilizing the RGB protocol,

The answer is...

Theoretically possible, particularly when considering the RGB25 standard.

However, there will be a significant journey ahead before it is applied in practice.

And Bitlight Labs is working on it.

Stay engaged with RGB protocol. Stay tuned with Bitlight Labs.

Thatâ€™s why we need #Bitcoin Layer2. 

Inscriptions cause UTXO set wasted, making Bitcoin cumbersome. 

#RGB protocol is the most scalable L2 solution, Turing-complete, UTXO-enabled, Lightning Network compatible, with native Bitcoin. 

#Bitcoin is great. What about a faster one?

Bitcoin miners can censor transactions - that is well known fact. 

What prevents global censorship? The requirement that before there is a miner controlling 50%+ hashrate there is a way to bribe a minor miner not to censor your transaction, and censorship at individual miner level before that threshold just results not in the global censorship but just in tx fee censorship (poor people will be censored).

Once we have 50%+-controlling miner the only way to prevent censorship is to run â€œreverse selfish-miningâ€ by controlling 33% of hash power, which is significantly more expensive than just bribing miners.

After a miner or their coalition control 66.7% of hash power, there is no way to escape censorship, even by utilizing â€œreverse selfish miningâ€ approach as in the case of 50%+.

The problem that miner pooling enables large miners coalitions and do unlock these 50%+ and 66%+ doomsday scenarios - and it is an old known problem. Stratum v2 was designed as a solution to it - however, even with it, pools still can be required to KYC their individual miners - the part which canâ€™t be solved at all.

Client-side-validation (like used in RGB) and blockchain-less approaches like Prime are the only solution to the censorship problem. Blockchain as a transparent data layer must die.

Thatâ€™s our focus at @lnp_bp

Most of our advice and help didnâ€™t create to any life-changing impact - our presence merely provided psychological support in their darkest time - but we did do one thing right: we advised them to stay on Solana.

In this process however, i learned most VCs actively advised them to switch to eth. This truly boggled my mind.

It is one thing to say â€œI donâ€™t know what will happen to Solanaâ€, it is yet another to actively and confidently advise founders to ditch Solana. â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€ is a perfectly fine answer, I myself frequently say this to @alliancedao founders.

But to confidently advise them to ditch Solana fundamentally assumes that itâ€™s more likely for Solana to die than to outcompete an Ethereum incumbent that have been around infinitely longer, have infinitely more resources, and have infinitely more users. This is such a fundamentally incoherent assumption I donâ€™t even know where to start.

That was when I realized, there are really so many fucking idiots managing so much money in this space arenâ€™t there. Excuse my language, but I was legit angry at the folks who were hurting my bags.

Later my anger subsided. I comforted myself saying if my founders actually listened to that advice, they themselves are the idiots, and ultimately Iâ€™m the idiot for backing them. Self-selection.

It turns that @0xrwu @_ilmoi @weremeow @y2kappa all chose to double down on Solana despite everyone telling them otherwise, and today they are all winning. 

The best founders seem to have this in common: they hear other peopleâ€™s advice, but they donâ€™t always listen to it. They know that ultimately, they themselves ought to be the domain experts.

Happy New Year

What a crazy crazy year

After some poor trading in 2022, Iâ€™d ran my portfolio down to 4 figs which is where I started the year and I would not have believed you if you told me Iâ€™d finish the year on 6 figs.

Especially after Iâ€™d reached 6 figs in July and lost it all back down to low 5 figs by end of August

Whats more valuable than the money Iâ€™ve made this year is the friends Iâ€™ve made along the way, and the lessons Iâ€™ve learnt from running up, nearly losing it all and then running up again. I keep a trading journal of my trades and no Iâ€™m not going to sit here and list my winners, instead Iâ€™m going to mostly talk about my mistakes as this is where Iâ€™ve learnt the most valuable lessons and Iâ€™d love to share these with you all in the hope that you too can learn from my mistakes:

1) Sizing

Sizing is so so important. The main reason Iâ€™d ran my port down twice is from poor sizing. I like to be aggressive with my trading style and my allocations but Iâ€™ve learnt to set myself limits. I was putting in 30-40% of my port on shitcoins and new launches (hello $bald lol) which repeatedly cost me. My new system with my port larger is now as following:

10-20% allocation per play depending on how early I think I am, and how high my conviction is. You want to make sure youâ€™re maximising your winners. For shitcoins/memes my limit is now 1% but in general since evaluating my journal Iâ€™ve tended to trade these less and less (see below). This is a system Iâ€™ve set as my port has grown. If you want to build quick with a smaller port then Iâ€™d split your port into 2-4 plays and then spread your risk more once youâ€™ve grown your port more.

Correct sizing also means you donâ€™t over react to red candles. This is a sign I use for myself to decide whether Iâ€™ve over allocated. If youâ€™ve over allocated to a play you will panic/worry/stress when it pulls backs, whereas if youâ€™ve sized well youâ€™re far less reactive. Correct sizing leads to better control of emotions.

2) 8 plays accounted for 70% of my profits.

This showed me that I only need a few good trades throughout the year and donâ€™t need to be constantly looking for new trades. In fact it's clear from my journal that over trading was a big profit killer for me. This also ties into sizing, unless Iâ€™m happy to put 10% of my portfolio into a play I tend to stay out (shitcoins aside) and this helps in limiting how many trades I take. Additionally I tended to perform better when I had around 6-8 plays in my port, which makes sense given I was able to keep up with all of them easier.

3) I entered a lot of losing trades straight after closing winning trades

This is something I noticed about halfway through the year; spurned on by the adrenaline of winning trades I would always look for a new trade for my next dopamine hit as soon as Iâ€™d closed the winning trade. This led to many rushed trades without thorough thinking and giving back profits fresh from a winning trade. Interestingly this is something I did far more than when Iâ€™d lost trades (I guess I was more aware of not chasing losses).

Whenever I close a trade now (winning or losing) I wait at least a few hours before entering a new trade just to make sure Iâ€™m thinking clearly and my judgment is unaffected by the emotions of a win or loss.

4) Ignore previous price action

Iâ€™m not saying enter a trade after itâ€™s done a 10x in one hour but instead what I mean is to make your decision on entering a trade based on where the price can go, as opposed to what the price has done so far. Earlier in the year I ignored some plays because theyâ€™ve already done a 2x and went onto lose out much much more. Imagine if we did this for $mubi $rlb or $unibot for example. Itâ€™s much better to decide where you think the price can go and see how far the play is from that price as opposed to worrying youâ€™re late and the opportunity has gone just because the price has already moved. Similar to this, if you think a coin can do a 5x, then don't fade it if it's moved 10-20%. 

5) Adjust your risk based on market conditions

I donâ€™t try and guess where btc is going to go and sell at the opportune moment to then buy back 10-20% lower. Looking back however I think itâ€™s important to at least adjust your risk/sizing based on market conditions. I should also have adjusted my targets. In poorer conditions you should lower your targets for exits in trades. For example from Jan-June and October-Dec we had really nice runs in the market whereas July-September was tougher. I lost a lot of capital in July-Sep as I was forcing trades and sizing as I was in the favourable conditions of the first half of the year. In hindsight I should have reduced my sizing and traded less when the market was tougher. I was too greedy and impatient.

Wait for good market conditions, donâ€™t force it in tougher conditions. Adjust your sizing/targets based on the market conditions.

6) New launches and shitcoins

These are the type of plays where I lost the most money. Yes ofc there is big gains to be made here too but personally this is not my edge and it became clear after a while that my success rate from these is poor. Allocate accordingly and limit how many of these type of trades you're taking, especially if you're newer to the game. Definitely an area for me to improve on in 2024. 

7) â€˜Psychological comfortâ€™ is an understated factor

I suppose this goes back to allocation and sizing again. When I had a smaller port I felt more comfortable being 100% allocated to active plays. As my port has grown however I've become more uncomfortable having 100% of my port in active positions. This is something well explained by @0x_Kun. The first time I ran my port to 6 figs I remained in nearly 100% active positions and this was psychologically uncomfortable. This led to me worrying more over fluctuations in my port and making some poor decisions as a result. What I like to do now is supply lp in tokenless projects with around 10-20% of my port. This creates a â€˜floorâ€™ for my port which I find more psychologically comfortable and results in me reacting less to price movements. Everyone will have a different tolerance to what % of their port theyâ€™re happy to have in active positions but my point here is to try and find that sweet spot for yourself as itâ€™ll allow you to remain calmer during pullbacks.

8) Keep a trading journal

Tbh I feel a lot of the points Iâ€™ve made are nothing new and youâ€™re likely aware of most already but having my journal and having a record of all my mistakes really drummed them all home for me. Iâ€™m a firm believer that we learn best from mistakes and the journal has been pivotal in this for me. Donâ€™t be afraid of losing money, itâ€™s part of the process.

9) Keeping your money is the most difficult skill to master

I've already learnt this the hard way twice over. I truly believe crypto is a gift for making life changing money for us all, and if you work hard and put the hours in you can make money from this, but the real trick is learning to keep it. This is part of the reason I like to set a 'floor' in my port too, and I've learnt to take profits to fiat once  in a while also. Whatever you do, make sure you have some sort of end plan, and be very protective over your money once you've made it. Don't suddenly start aping into anything that comes around.

10) Your network is the most valuable asset in this space

Lastly it only feels right to give credit to the people whoâ€™ve really helped me on this journey and to those who Iâ€™ve learned so much from. Iâ€™m under no illusions that I wouldnâ€™t have achieved anywhere near what I have without those around me:

Hedera WalletConnect Working Group November 10th Meeting Recording ğŸ¬

Today, representatives from Hedera wallets gathered to discuss the ongoing progress of this community initiative and to vote on key decisions.

In the thread below, you'll find links to the meeting notes, project milestones, HIP-820 and the Github repository. These materials contain all the information discussed in the meeting.

This group's collective goal is to complete open source development of reference implementations (aka a library/SDK) of the official Hedera @WalletConnect spec and perform a successful handoff to the community before the end of the year.

A huge shoutout to the teams at @HashPackApp, @KabilaApp, @droppcc, @CalaxyApp, @wallawallet and @BladeWallet for their incredible leadership and to @swirldslabs for enabling this initiative.

Thank you to the whole @Hedera community for all your support. Please get involved with this initiative and reach out anytime, there is an onboarding form in the thread. This meeting was hosted by @itsbrandond from @_ddstyle and @SplashGraph , CEO of Hgraph.

WalletConnect for Hedera (Coming Soon) ğŸ“£

Hgraph is leading a joint initiative with key wallet providers to create a unified @WalletConnect solution for the @Hedera ecosystem. This streamlined library/SDK will simplify processes for dapps and pave the way for accelerated mass adoption.

One integration for all wallets!

Following months of dedication from all involved providers, we're now entering the "Community Beta" phase, allowing dapps & wallets to start testing WalletConnect. As we progress towards finalizing the reference implementations (library/SDK) of the official Hedera WalletConnect spec, stay tuned for more detailed updates coming soon.

Every wallet provider is actively supporting this initiative, working together and coming to consensus on each step of the way. Each provider has made significant compromises for the benefit of the Hedera community and we are incredibly grateful. These collective efforts not only strengthen our ecosystem but also showcase its resilience.

We'd like to express our gratitude to the teams at @HashPackApp, @KabilaApp, @droppcc, @CalaxyApp, @BladeWallet, @wallawallet and other providers participating in this initiative. We're also thankful to the independent experts advising our group, as well as @_ddstyle for overseeing the project management.

If you're actively engaged in the Hedera wallet ecosystem and wish to contribute, we welcome you to our collaborative effort. We've provided a helper library, a HIP, and forums for dialogue. You can find details about these resources in the thread accompanying this post.

Stay tuned for updates and share this exciting news! We welcome your feedback and questions and promise to address them swiftly and openly. We value our community's input and we canâ€™t wait for whatâ€™s to come!

A cool use case for Newsly profiles: Expected News

There are often scenarios in crypto where a certain piece of news is expected or intimated. This can be something broader like the ETF announcement or DOJ (Binance case). 

Lately, it's become common for teams to do 'announcements of announcements'. These usually have steady buildups and then volatility during the actual announcement. 

1) $GRT 

GRT pumped nearly 50% after the announcement of announcement. In this case, they gave a specific day but no time when the announcement would be dropped. The announcement was overhyped but due to risk-on market conditions, there was no significant dump on the news. 

2) $OCEAN

In this case, the exact time was given for the announcement. It took place in worse market conditions and we got a full bart. 

Newsly Profiles

In all of these cases, it's useful to have a separate notification stream. Whether you're already in the position and will need to make a decision on the announcement or whether you want to short if the announcement is lackluster. 

You can create a new profile for any piece of expected news, pin the channel so it's always on top, and turn on loud notifications. 

You can then filter the profiles to only bring news with the keyword "GRT" or "Ocean" for example. 

It's simple and takes 5 min to set up, join the TG if you need help setting it up and I or any team member can assist

Example profile: 

ETF News
Include keywords: ETF, blackrock, ishares, ericbalchunas

- From 0 to 40+ private audits with some of the biggest names ( @graphprotocol @Optimism @BadgerDAO @reserveprotocol @lukso_io @stellaxyz_  )
- 20 paid bounty reports, many on OG protocols (@chainlink @aave @Uniswap @OpenZeppelin @SushiSwap @deBridgeFinance  @SpookySwap +++)
- Strategic retainers locked in
- Onboarded 10 fantastic auditors & bug hunters
- Connected with the ecosystem in Paris @summit_defi @EthCC 

All of this would not have been possible without our great team. I'm extremely proud of your commitment to detail, perfection, and team spirit in everything you do.

Personally I've also found time to cherry pick a couple of public contests and give back with judging roles:
- Sherlock Optimism January/March contests - Both first place collab with the magical @zachobront 
- C4 - ENS (1st), Chainlink CCIP (4th), Basin (1st)

In 2024 we will strive to continue safeguarding as many protocols as possible and achieve even greater impact. We'll continue to expand our reach while maintaining the quality our clients have come to expect.

Finally, a small announcement: Next year we will be hosting the first TrustCTF. The goal is to bring together devs, auditors and pro bounty hunters for a shared educational/competitive experience. Some quick reporting tips for auditors:
- The title should just mention the high level impact and name the primary component/s. If it is not readable by a non-tech executive, re-write it.
- The description needs to start with a summary of the functionalities in play, then dive into the root cause, and finally outline the scenario that achieves the highest impact.
- When suggesting fixes, spend an extra 10 minutes considering if these would introduce new issues and if so, include those risks in the mitigation section.
- Use client's test suite to provide POCs instead of writing from scratch. It would be more readable for them and they get free regression tests.

Above tips apply for reports on all platforms & audits. Will share reporting & negotiating guidelines for bounty submissions soon.

The formula is missing one massive detail: the star factor.
A solo 0.01% auditor will usually beat 30 average auditors, even if they have the same "experience" points. 
Now the question becomes: where is the highest (skill x headcount) product found?

As an industry one of the things we MUST improve is assigning severities to bugs. Most firms are supposedly following impact/likelihood table but when diving in, you see massive gaps in judgement or outright ignoring of the criteria.
It seems competitive platforms and firms employing contest judges produce reports with most intellectual integrity. Makes sense, as judges are used to downgrading severities and have natural checks and balances.
But "why is this an issue?" one may ask, as the bug will be fixed regardless. Well, in the Wild West of audit firms, the dishonest actors stand to gain as very few clients have the will to dig in and validate the quality behind the numbers. Honest firms lose out by not bumping severities for marketing. 
Bottom line is that projects will feel a false sense of security. And that IS a big issue.
Conditions are ripe for establishing a globally respected bug-rating firm. If no one does it, I will.

By engineering innovative modular rollup infrastructure and forging strategic partnerships, we've been pivotal in shaping a blockchain world that supports tens of thousands of rollups.   
https://t.co/HBaO98QV9Q

If we believe in the rollup-centric future of Ethereum, the importance of services like @alt_layer's 'Restaked Rollups' will become significantly greater.

While general-purpose rollups like @optimsimFND, @arbitrum, @0xPolygon may be able to develop their own decentralized sequencing and verification systems, in a future with tens of thousands of rollups, it will be difficult for every rollup to build these systems independently.

'Restaked Rollups' utilizes 3 vertically integrated AVSs. These AVSs offer 1) Decentralized Sequencing, 2) Verifying, and 3) Fast Finality. All these features are based on the economic security of ETH restaked on EigenLayer, making them secure.

After considerable internal debate and in consultation with our Board of Directors, effective Wednesday, September 27, 2023 at 8am PST Blocknative will suspend our MEV-Boost Relay and associated Ethereum Block Builders. Our Relay Data API will remain available for data downloads until October 4, 2023. 

We do not anticipate this change disrupting Validator, Builder, Searcher, or other network operations. To avoid any error messages after September 27, please modify your configurations as follows: 

ğŸŸ¦Validators: The Blocknative Relay will return a 503 error with â€œno builder bidâ€. Ensure your Validators are connected to multiple MEV-Boost Relays and have local building enabled. Remove the Blocknative Relay from your Validator configurations.

ğŸŸ¦Third-Party Block Builders: Blocks you submit to the Blocknative Relay will return 503 error codes. Please remove the Blocknative relay from your submission list.

ğŸŸ¦Searchers: Bundles you submit to the Blocknative auction gateway will return a 503 error code. Please remove the Blocknative endpoint from your configuration.

ğŸŸ¦Blocknative Protect Users: Please update your RPC endpoint to the Transaction Boost endpoint: https://t.co/Cr6uuM9UXM. Otherwise, when sending a transaction, you will receive a 503 error code.

We are making these changes to focus our efforts on economically viable opportunities that align with our values, interests, and capabilities.
If you have questions, please reach out to us on Discord or send us a DM here. ğŸ«¡

In 2022, the Venom Foundation was established under the ADGM Foundations Regulations 2017. We announce that as of December 14, 2023, Venom Foundation will no longer continue operating in ADGM and in accordance with section 40 of the regulations, the Foundation has initiated the dissolution process.

This decision aligns with our current strategic direction. It is important to highlight that our choice to dissolve is specific to our present objectives and not a reflection on the ADGM environment. Looking ahead, the Venom Foundation remains open to exploring future opportunities within ADGM.

Please note that as of today there has been no token generation event. Any public statement that the Venom Foundation has issued a Venom token following a token generation event is untrue and has not been authorized by the foundation.

Dear Venom community ğŸ’š

We have not launched Mainnet. When we launch; you, our trusted family members will be the first to know.

Beware of fake news and dishonest scammers.

Thanks for your support and following, stay tuned to our official channels on discord, or here on X.

JUST IN: ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ SEC may notify issuers about Spot #Bitcoin ETF approval as soon as Tuesday or Wednesday, Reuters reports.

DeFi Predictions for 2024

1. Delta Neutral Stables becomes a new trend

+ Algo stable coins died off significantly since the $UST collapse
+ 2023 saw LSD Stable Trending 
+ $LYBRA , $PRISMA & a few others picked up significant TVL.
+ These projects allowed user to gain price exposure to $ETH while earning yields on composable stable coins
+ In 2024, projects like @ethena_labs ( $USDe ) will offer users an attractive alternative for stables.
+ Give up the upside of $ETH for a delta neutral stable with increased yield bearing opportunities. 
+ LSD Stables ~ 6% APR vs Delta Neu Stables ~ 15-30%
+ Also seeing stables being build on complex strategies like CEX Futures vs spot arbitrages and other forms of Delta Neutral Strategies.
+ The safety net of zero price exposure and increased yields will be a tempting proposition to institutions w large treasuries. 
+ Expecting Delta Neutral Stables to pick up significant TVL in 2024.

2. AI gets used more widely in DeFi and NFTs

+ The AI sector will continue to pick up traction in the web3 space.
+ AI generated NFTs become the norm
+ AI-driven predictive analytics using on chain data will allow projects to optimize tokenomics and study demand patterns
+ AI-driven Vaults will be created to automatically conduct simple yield farming strategies with auto hedging

3. BRC20 Ecosystem TVL boom

+ 2023 saw the rise of BRC20 and the $STX ecosystem
+ The current DeFi landscape on BRC20 is still pretty barren but i expect traction to pick up significantly in 2024.
+ Many BRC20 to EVM bridges have been popping up over the past few months ~ $MUBI, $BRGE & @XLinkbtc 
+ The friction between EVM layers and BRC20 would be significantly lower in 2024 and allow TVL to flow between the ecosystems.
+ DeFi projects looking for ecosystems with lower competition would likely launch on @Stacks 
+ Expect the same suite of projects on EVM layers to be launched on BRC20 ( Bribing DEX, VeMoney Markets,  CDP Stables, Yield Vaults...)
+ Users looking to enter early will flood the ecoystem and normies who only know $BTC will offer fresh capital inflows post ETF approval.

4. Modular Blockchains to gain further traction in TXs and TVL

+ More L1 / L2 Projects will continue to be launched
+ Efficiency and adaptability would play a key role in blockchains adapting to changing narratives and needs of the users.
+ EIP-4844 (Proto-Danksharding) will greatly reduce gas cost of L2s
+ Modular blockchains can further reduce cost using data availability layers like @eigenlayer or @NEARProtocol 
+ Modular L2s are likely be able to offer Txs below $0.01 and be more appealing to dApps which require high TX Vol like games or CLOBs.
+ Composability w restaking narrative also gives modular blockchains a slight edge against their Monolithic peers
+ Notable Modular Blockchains @0xMantle , @EclipseFND & @fuel_network 

5. DEX Trading vol vs CEX to increase

+ DEXes will eat into CEX market share as the barriers to access DEXes continue to be lowered
+ Dapps are finally focusing on being mobile friendly and accessible to users on the go
+ @Uniswap and @1inch launching their mobile Dapps are just the beginning
+ Newer Perps Dapps like @IntentX_ , @HyperliquidX & @OfficialApeXdex allows users to easily trade perps on the go.
+ Intent based RFQ architecture allows dapps to eliminate MEV attacks on TXs and reduce slippages
+ RFQ architecture also increases the range of asset offerings to users and give users the availability of choice
+ All these factors lead to improved UX for users and narrows the gap between offerings from CEXes while allowing users to retain asset custody

Thats all folks~

Looking forward to 2024. Cheers!

+ Also seeing stables being build on complex strategies like CEX Futures vs spot arbitrages and other forms of Delta Neutral Strategies.
+ The safety net of zero price exposure and increased yields will be a tempting proposition to institutions w large treasuries. 
+ Expecting Delta Neutral Stables to pick up significant TVL in 2024.

2. AI gets used more widely in DeFi and NFTs

+ The AI sector will continue to pick up traction in the web3 space.
+ AI generated NFTs become the norm
+ AI-driven predictive analytics using on chain data will allow projects to optimize tokenomics and study demand patterns
+ AI-driven Vaults will be created to automatically conduct simple yield farming strategies with auto hedging

3. BRC20 Ecosystem TVL boom

+ 2023 saw the rise of BRC20 and the $STX ecosystem
+ The current DeFi landscape on BRC20 is still pretty barren but i expect traction to pick up significantly in 2024.
+ Many BRC20 to EVM bridges have been popping up over the past few months ~ $MUBI, $BRGE & @XLinkbtc 
+ The friction between EVM layers and BRC20 would be significantly lower in 2024 and allow TVL to flow between the ecosystems.
+ DeFi projects looking for ecosystems with lower competition would likely launch on @Stacks 
+ Expect the same suite of projects on EVM layers to be launched on BRC20 ( Bribing DEX, VeMoney Markets,  CDP Stables, Yield Vaults...)
+ Users looking to enter early will flood the ecoystem and normies who only know $BTC will offer fresh capital inflows post ETF approval.

4. Modular Blockchains to gain further traction in TXs and TVL

+ More L1 / L2 Projects will continue to be launched
+ Efficiency and adaptability would play a key role in blockchains adapting to changing narratives and needs of the users.
+ EIP-4844 (Proto-Danksharding) will greatly reduce gas cost of L2s
+ Modular blockchains can further reduce cost using data availability layers like @eigenlayer or @NEARProtocol 
+ Modular L2s are likely be able to offer Txs below $0.01 and be more appealing to dApps which require high TX Vol like games or CLOBs.
+ Composability w restaking narrative also gives modular blockchains a slight edge against their Monolithic peers
+ Notable Modular Blockchains @0xMantle , @EclipseFND & @fuel_network 

5. DEX Trading vol vs CEX to increase

+ DEXes will eat into CEX market share as the barriers to access DEXes continue to be lowered
+ Dapps are finally focusing on being mobile friendly and accessible to users on the go
+ @Uniswap and @1inch launching their mobile Dapps are just the beginning
+ Newer Perps Dapps like @IntentX_ , @HyperliquidX & @OfficialApeXdex allows users to easily trade perps on the go.
+ Intent based RFQ architecture allows dapps to eliminate MEV attacks on TXs and reduce slippages
+ RFQ architecture also increases the range of asset offerings to users and give users the availability of choice
+ All these factors lead to improved UX for users and narrows the gap between offerings from CEXes while allowing users to retain asset custody

Thats all folks~

Looking forward to 2024. Cheers!

TLDR:

$AVAX Foundation is bidding meme coins. 

Rofl.

Last year, the Avalanche Foundation launched Culture Catalyst, a program aimed at empowering creators, sparking innovation, and propelling the adoption of blockchains. This initiative seeks to better position Avalanche to cultivate and support the many new forms of creativity, culture, and lifestyle that blockchain enables.

Alongside prominent cryptoasset categories like gas tokens, DeFi tokens, Real World Assets (RWAs), NFTs, stablecoins, and governance coins, meme coins have carved out a significant niche in the cryptoasset landscape. These coins, often inspired by internet culture and humor, go beyond mere utility assets; they represent the collective spirit and shared interests of diverse crypto communities.

The Avalanche Foundation intends to start using Culture Catalyst to recognize and encourage the culture and fun symbolized by meme coins by purchasing select Avalanche-based meme coins to create a collection. This move complements the Avalanche Foundation's ongoing engagement across the Avalanche ecosystem, including NFTs, RWAs, and other types of cryptoassets, broadening its portfolio to embrace a more complete spectrum of possibilities. 

The selection process for this collection is based on several key criteria, including the number of holders, liquidity thresholds, project maturity, principles of a fair launch, and overall social sentiment, among other factors. 

The Avalanche Foundation is dedicated to supporting diverse and culturally significant initiatives, establishing its position as an adaptable and inclusive participant in the Web3 space.

Itâ€™s increasingly clear to me that the dominant narrative over the next few months will be centered on Bitcoin and the ecosystems recently being developed around it.

The ETF and the upcoming halving merely set the stage for a Bitcoin focus. Meanwhile, Chinese traders are in a growing frenzy over Bitcoin inscriptions and ordinals while exchanges have signaled support with BRC-20 listings and wallet integrations. 'Frenzy' is possibly even an understatement- OKXâ€™s NFT marketplace has now passed Blur in total sales on its ordinals volume alone. And despite all this, Western markets have barely even begun to pick up on the narrative, hinting at how early it likely still is.

Being bullish on all things Bitcoin, I think the obvious next step is still for Bitcoin L2s to see price discovery as people accept that scaling solutions will become a key part of the Bitcoin ecosystem's future. Itâ€™s highly possible that this could lead to an entire price re-rating as people realize that the leading Bitcoin L2s should have multi-billion dollar valuations. With the alt L1 thesis largely played out the last few weeks, a Bitcoin rotation on the back of the ETF, halving, and Ordinals logically makes sense.

Alongside an obvious core BTC spot long, I continue to favor Stacks as a likely contender to lead the L2 battle, and think certain exchange listed BRC-20 tokens can continue to squeeze hard as western markets pick up the trend.

since everyone is giving their ETF market predictions, gun to my head...

next 1-1.5 weeks leading up to decision: $BTC chops in $40k range while $ETH gains dominance and most $ALTS continue to cool off.

$BTC upside pre-ETF is shorter because most front run flows are over and remaining sidelined capital is more likely to buy the "next asset" now, which explains what we're seeing in crypto stocks and $ETH.

however people who want to front run "selling the news" are also more likely to have done so by now. imo we saw a lot of it last week on both CB and CME. remaining capital that wants to exit may do so on Jan 1 for tax deferral in the last week before a decision.

so increasingly likely that $BTC has found it's pre-decision range and deviations to either side give last minute participants a chance to enter/exit.

I think 40k floor will be defended and 45k will be hard to break pre-decision, but possible if sellers exhaust after Jan 1 and Saylor goes schizo mode (although time to file for a new equity raise makes window very small).

if $ALTS ever need an excuse to correct it would be after a mega rally with lots of built up leverage and right before a highly uncertain event with a known date...

$ETH underperformed both sides and is likely to mean revert now as the next big catalyst trade (ETF/EIP4844), grinding higher. ETH beta will continue to suck flows from other alts in this case.

base case on announcement of ETF approval is algo's push $BTC higher then sell for 5-10%, price fully retraces creating jedi candlestick. from there we have a few days or couple weeks max until etf launch. sell the newsoors are out and price grinds up into launch as hype/marketing circulates and people are optimistic.

price action on launch date depends entirely on ETF flows, will be extremely volatile, but imo will be hard to beat expectations and fears around grayscale (and now gox/celsius selling) may resurface. first couple days may disappoint as a result, timeline calls for full retrace back to low 30k's and we probably don't get there before stabilizing and grinding back up because big picture is bullish now and most of ct has not grasped the macro shift yet. all time highs by eoy?

needless to say the path is extremely hard to predict, I'm just going out on a limb here but take it with a grain of salt. positioning > predicting. especially around major events with high uncertainty. just make sure you're positioned comfy for any scenario.

Orb Labs is excited to deliver intent-driven interoperability to chains that leverage CelestiaDA

Orb Labs designs our products with intent(ion). Orby and the Orb Stack are designed for seamless single-chain interoperability. Let's dive into how we're solving the interop puzzle ğŸ§©: https://t.co/ZGdGht4a7S

The number of chains is growing ğŸŒ±and with each new chain, account fragmentation gets worse.

To use an app on any chain, users must maintain an account on that chain. So if users are using apps across 10 different chains, the user must maintain 10 different accounts which is tedious and unpleasant. Users would much rather limit their interaction to a few chains.

Without a solution for account fragmentation, apps also are likely to aggregate around a handful of chains, based on community metrics like # of active users, etc. Even if a new chain or building an appchain is more optimized for their needs, the fear of an empty room is too daunting.

To thrive, single-chain apps need solutions that enable them to access to users on other chains and streamline user interactions. Essentially, solutions addressing the account fragmentation problem. ğŸ§©

That is our goal at Orb labs. We are building a unique intent-driven-interop stack that enables developers to build on any chain that best suits their app while allowing them to access any users on any chain.

To learn more, please read: https://t.co/RJ2so1DqZV

Orb Labs focuses on building interoperability solutions for single-chain applications.
But what are single-chain applications? ğŸ¤”

Single-chain apps, as the name suggests, confine all their logic and processes to one blockchain.
They come in several forms:

ğŸ’» Applications deployed on one chain,
e.g. @friendtech is built on Base and does not live on any other chain.

ğŸ–¥ï¸ Applications deployed on multiple chains without interacting components,
e.g. @Uniswap is deployed on multiple chains, but each deployment does not interact with other chains, making each deployment a single-chain app.

â›“ï¸App-chains, e.g. @dydx.

Two potential corollaries for assets in other markets and SOL.

NVDA - Built in narrow space alongside behemoths, was malleable due to structural technological advantages to capture multiple narratives, had massive industry tailwinds, but many other companies in the space still that could become very large (on both public + private semis side, as well as obviously the cloud businesses of big tech). Also, possible we see high volatility in the asset (SOL) relative to others that have strong consistent performance (ETH). You could even take this a step further and look at how NVDA materially outperformed AMD over this run up due to better software (CUDA) and thus performance, but worst cost structures.

This framing is a little overly bullish imo but it's interesting.

--

TSLA as a corollary for SOL may actually be the best one though if we think about market structures and how major participants look at an asset moving from an "alt" to a "blue chip" within their category, all while defying fundamental analysis for a long period of time, but capturing large narrative value and technology premium along the way. You could even say the disruption of Monolithic vs. Modular is similar to EV vs. Combustion engine.

This isn't the right asset framing entirely from a broader industry returns perspective though as auto OEMs largely have underperformed, however if you put TSLA in context of FAANG, then perhaps this is a stronger argument.

Anyways, just some half-baked thoughts while sitting at the airport.

I've been doing a bit of consulting work for a startup with a product that records brain activity and then non-invasively stimulates areas of the brain to induce certain cognitive states. They're focused on a very specific use case, but this kind of non pharmacological brain intervention is going to go mainstream in the next 5-10 years. 

I've tweeted about LG's earbuds that measure your brainwaves and induces deeper sleep, and Apple was recently granted a patent for in-ear EEG. Halo was doing trans-cranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in a pair of headphones to try and improve athletic performance before Flow acquired them. 

This research has been going on in labs for 15-20 years in earnest, and tDCS goes back over 100 years. But we seem to be at an inflection point where it's coming out of the lab and into the world. 

Obviously there are limitations to what's possible. But imagine a device that could treat depression, or help you focus, or make you less anxious and more happy, without any drugs involved. With the right instruments you can target and stimulate millimeter sized regions of the brain. A lot is going to be possible without invasive brain surgery and things like Neuralink

Collateralized debt positions (CDPs) and Lending protocols have increased capital efficiency for DeFi natives and provided the means for profitable strategies. 

However, they are not without their own shortcomings.

The reliance on smart contracts introduces vulnerability to potential bugs and external attacks, posing inherent risks to the security and stability of CDPs. 

This is why the code @AureliusFi [the Ethos reserve code base] has been audited multiple times over, and checks put in place. 

In 2022, about $4B in DeFi investorâ€™s funds were stolen by hackers. Attacks of this scales pose a significant threat, particularly to CDPs and lending protocols as economic pitfalls that occur as a result of hacks can lead to death spirals and the potential collapse of products.

Below are some of the hacks and bugs that were recorded in the CDP and lending space this year:

1) Euler Finance hack (April, 2023)

The eToken.sol contract permitted the generation of an unlimited quantity of tokens for any collateral value, resulting in a simultaneous increase in debt tokens (dToken). This allowed users to amass as much collateral as desired while expanding their debt. Additionally, the protocol facilitated the contribution of assets to the market reserve through the eToken's donateToReserves function.

The issue arose from the absence of a health ratio check in this function. This lapse, combined with the capability to accumulate collateral, introduced the potential for liquidating a position with substantial profit.

2) ParaSpace hack (March, 2023)

ParaSpace is a lending protocol where users can use NFTs from top collections like BAYC as collateral. The protocol also allowed the use of APE tokens to collateralize positions, which were initially staked on the official Yuga Labs contract from the protocol's contract address.

Instead of getting APE tokens, users received cAPE tokens, and the cAPE balance was determined by the user's share from the ParaSpace staking pool multiplied by the total APE tokens locked by the protocol.

The problem in the system was that the total APE tokens staked by the protocol could be manipulated. This happened because the APE staking contract from Yuga Labs permitted deposits from any address to any address.

By exploiting a flashloan, the attacker manipulated the total number of APE tokens locked in the protocol, consequently altering their cAPE balance.

3) Tigris Trade Audit (December, 2022)

Tigris Trade enabled users to put in one stablecoin as collateral and take out another. However, there was an issue found by the auditor. In this instance, a user could deposit a stablecoin worth 0.95 USD (not pegged properly) and withdraw a stablecoin worth a full 1 USD (properly pegged).

This would cause the protocol to lose 0.05 USD for each token.

4) Astaria Audit (October, 2022)

During the liquidation auction, bids were accepted in the form of token transfers to a contract. If one person's bidding interrupted someone else's bid, the initial bidder was supposed to get their money back. Unfortunately, a problem was found in the cancelAuction() function. This bug caused the last bid not to be returned to the original bidder, leading to the funds getting stuck in the contract.

These are a few cases where  vulnerabilities were exploited and few where they were prevented (audit cases).

These events serve as a chilling reminder that money markets are not perfect yet and hence carry a certain level of inherent risk, one you should be familiar with.

With our multiple audits, and checks in place, we seek to provide you a safe and secure experience. Coming soon to Mantle.

The first computer art tools were pixel editors, the apex of which was Deluxe Paint for the Amiga. Then Photoshop came in and changed the paradigm to image editing: old schoolers laughed at it because its pixel tools were so weak, but there was magic in changing the conceptual focus to the image and often editing it at a much higher resolution than the display. Iâ€™ve come to recognize generative AI art as the next paradigm change, away from drawing the image, towards specifying a scene through a combination of prompts, infills, and hand edits - whatever gets to the best result fastest. Fine Photoshop artists lament it (and shady IP practices warrant their respective criticisms) but ultimately itâ€™s a new tool with a new paradigm that will likely become the predominant one in the future.

And though the current tools are all about images, theyâ€™re rapidly evolving into video and 3D scenes, the ultimate version of which may be full 3D scene and animated shot synthesis and tweaking at professional levels of quality. For those born after the birth of the personal computer and the internet, itâ€™ll be oneâ€™s first contact with a complete technological upheaval.

The rapid burst of progress over the past 18 months in chat and art may be a bit misleading though, as they were preceded by 3 decades of directly applicable foundational research. Some areas of future AI application are lacking in these foundations, so we can expect progress to come in fits and starts. But the exponential upward trend is unmistakable.

h2oGPT: Democratizing Large Language Models

paper page: https://t.co/L7Lqn5jZYp

Foundation Large Language Models (LLMs) such as GPT-4 represent a revolution in AI due to their real-world applications though natural language processing. However, they also pose many significant risks such as the presence of biased, private, or harmful text, and the unauthorized inclusion of copyrighted material. We introduce h2oGPT, a suite of open-source code repositories for the creation and use of Large Language Models (LLMs) based on Generative Pretrained Transformers (GPTs). The goal of this project is to create the world's best truly open-source alternative to closed-source GPTs. In collaboration with and as part of the incredible and unstoppable open-source community, we open-source several fine-tuned h2oGPT models from 7 to 40 Billion parameters, ready for commercial use under fully permissive Apache 2.0 licenses. Included in our release is 100% private document search using natural language. Open-source language models help boost AI development and make it more accessible and trustworthy. They lower entry hurdles, allowing people and groups to tailor these models to their needs. This openness increases innovation, transparency, and fairness.

Today 6 years ago, "Attention is All You Need" went on Arxiv! Happy birthday Transformer! ğŸ‚

Fun facts:
- Transformer did not invent attention, but pushed it to the extreme. The first attention paper was published 3 years prior (2014) and had an unassuming title: "Neural Machine Translation by Jointly Learning to Align and Translate", from Yoshua Bengio's lab. 
It is a combination of RNN + "context vectors" (i.e. attention). Many of you likely haven't heard about this paper, but it's one of the greatest milestones in NLP and has been cited 29K times (compared to Transformer's 77K).

- Neither Transformer nor the original attention paper talked about the general-purpose sequence computer. Instead, both were conceived as solutions to one narrow & specific problem: machine translation. It's remarkable that AGI (some day soon) can trace its origin to the humble Google Translate. ğŸ˜…

- Transformer was published at NeurIPS 2017, one of the top AI conferences worldwide. Yet it didn't even get an Oral presentation, let alone awards. There were 3 best papers at NeurIPS that year. Combined, they have 529 citations as of today.

The market expects big moves ahead of the upcoming decision on $BTC ETF in January.

How do I know it?

Implied Volatility is increasing and the higher the traders are willing to pay for the options (i.e the higher the IV),

The more it means they expect a big movement to happen, otherwise, they wouldn't overpay.

As we see, UCVI increased by 61% (or almost by 1000% with the option to apply a 16x leverage) in the last 12 days.

This signals that the market is gearing up for higher volatility, and this might be just the beginning.

For those who forgot, @official_CVI Crypto Volatility Index tracks the price of out-the-money $BTC, $ETH, etc options with expiration dates near 30 days,

And shows the market's expectation of the volatility, rather than current or historic market levels.

Now I'm writing about AI, blockchain and tech to an audience that I couldn't be more grateful for.

This is more true of Crypto than any other niche.

Someone asked me a great question:

What would I do if I was just starting off in Web 3?

My answer:

â€¢ Study something new every day
â€¢ Engage with 2 to 4 quality conversations per day
â€¢ Share my insights every week with a twitter thread & article

And then listen.

6 choices I made that vastly improved my life:

1. Starting my gym journey
2. Reading one book a week
3. Deleting TradingView & TikTok
4. Having zero recurring meetings
5. Going to bed & waking up at the same time
6. Surrounding myself with smarter people than myself

3 simple ideas from the week:

(1) Big tech partnerships are way too overrated by crypto investors

(2) It's extremely difficult to incentivize creating public goods in crypto

(3) Anyone not focusing on the FED & rates are purposefully hurting their investments

Making money in crypto is more difficult than you think.

Everyone wanted to make 100x profits in the space of a week.

Now, 90% of the space is silent.

If you've been around long enough you know that this is the time to start learning about future narratives.

How to get a job in Web 3 â¬‡ï¸

1. Study a set of skills
2. Focus in on a niche
3. Advertise your expertise
4. Leverage your experience

4 steps that require dedication & consistency more than anything.

Marketing a project/protocol is such an undervalued skill.

If you don't enjoy coding then learn how to write/advertise effectively.

Learn how to use social media platforms effectively.

Remember, the community is always built from the ground up.
All roads that lead to success have to pass through hard work.

One quality of good art is the variance in its interpretation.

When some view The Nakamoto, they see a dank Pepe.

When others view The Nakamoto, they see a trading card that brings them back to the PvP games and collecting of their childhood.

But do you see what I see?

The Nakamoto is the memorial of Satoshi made immortal by the blockchain. It is a glorious tribute to whoever started this all. It is the headstone of a legend. The epitaph of a saint.

It is the most important piece in all of cryptoart. It is only a matter of time before this is no longer controversial.

Do we think too much about Punks as an entire collection?

Is there a reality where the divergence we already see in desired and rare traits (Hoodies, Aliens) continues to grow at a faster rate than the floor price -- creating a world where the floors on some traits appreciates to millions, or tens of millions of dollars, while floor Punks remain in the few hundred thousand dollar range forever?

The quicket way to die is to listen to people who tell you to kill your ego

This is a lie told to you by the people around you because they either do not understand your brilliance, do not know how to foster it, or simply do not want you to be better than them

In brilliant people, the ego creates a hatred of anything not exceptional that non-brilliant people perceive as immorality. They cannot understand it

Jobs was both one of the most egotistical people in the world and one of it's greatest ever entrepreneurs

His ego created the delusional self-belief necessary to achieve greatness. He tricked himself into believing he could achieve 100x more than he was capable of, and it worked. 

To tell him to kill this ego would have been to kill the very thing that made him Jobs

And those who couldn't stand his outbursts believed this was a fault of his own emotional regulation. They were wrong. It was their own fault of not being able to recognize a legend when one was standing right in front of them. They became upset because they felt they had some sort of part to play in the story - that they were somehow on equal playing ground. Again, they were wrong. Nobody remembers the names of these people

These people believe that somehow the egotist is making a mistake. That they will come to regret their behavior. Again, they are wrong. They do not understand the brilliant mind - the only thing it is interested in is the one thing it can see: greatness

Many of Michael Jordan's teammates hated him too.

But not once has Jobs or Jordan ever gone on the record to say that their goal was to make friends - to make those around them feel comfortable and wanted

You can get with the program, or you can get out

Remember that Kings are not painted with smiles

You can be brilliant with a few friends

Or you can be kind and nice and not offend anybody with a few more friends

But the worst thing you can do is deny your proclivities because you think it will make the people around you more comfortable because they will not be forced to contend with your brilliance

The only thing this will do is kill your spirit. And then they will forget your brilliance, and they will assert themselves on top of you

Nobody who tells you to kill your ego has your best interests at heart

Your hatred is what makes you strong. Only those who do not understand this power will tell you to stamp it out

This message pertains to @avant_arte and @avant_arte only.

It should not be construed as a critique (or, worse -- a complaint) of @lphaCentauriKid.

The fact that so many are up-in-arms about this drop is evidence of how coveted his work is and how important he is as an artist to the space.

The demand for Warothy, along with its immediately multiplied value of retail to resale on secondary is nothing but good for holders of his work (like myself).

The art itself is fantastic - the last minute 1/1/25 twist was totally unforeseen. The portraits are dark, storied, rich, emotive, and distinct. Where the original 1/25 would've been awesome, the 1/1/25 feels like a more connected extension of his work.

I wholeheartedly congratulate him on the sales.

Art collecting in this space is funny.

The bigger collector, the more they will speak about â€œdoing it for the cultureâ€, â€œthe artâ€ and â€œnever sellingâ€..

Yet, they will almost certainly never give one of their grails to a smaller collector. They will definitely not let a smaller collector win an auction if itâ€™s a piece they so desire. And even when there is equal opportunity for smaller collectors like a raffle, the big collector seemingly never steps aside.

And I think all of this is entirely reasonable. In fact, I would almost definitely do it myself. But I wouldnâ€™t also parade that Iâ€™m â€œnot in it for the moneyâ€ - this is a hypocrisy because there is a clear divergence between words and actions.

purely hypothetical: a protocol receives a critical bug disclosure. exploiting the bug, out of the total user funds one can only recover X%, (100-X)% will be locked up as part of the hack, forever unrecoverable. They have two options:

1) hack their own protocol, users only receive X% of their funds back
2) tell their users to withdraw, users who withdraw receive 100% of their funds back. but this communication risks the attention of blackhats who might steal everything.

As a protocol user, how low does the recoverable fund percentage X have to drop for you to prefer the adoption of the riskier strategy 2 instead of strategy 1?

The investigation continues, here is the timeline of what we know about the exploit at this moment:

- This morning CET, a former Ledger Employee fell victim to a phishing attack that gained access to their NPMJS account.
- The attacker published a malicious version of the Ledger Connect Kit (affecting versions 1.1.5, 1.1.6, and 1.1.7). The malicious code used a rogue WalletConnect project to reroute funds to a hacker wallet.
- Ledgerâ€™s technology and security teams were alerted and a fix was deployed within 40 minutes of Ledger becoming aware. The malicious file was live for around 5 hours, however we believe the window where funds were drained was limited to a period of less than two hours.
- Ledger coordinated with @WalletConnect who quickly disabled the the rogue project.
- The genuine and verified Ledger Connect Kit version 1.1.8 is now propagating and is safe to use.
- For builders who are developing and interacting with the Ledger Connect Kit code: connect-kit development team  on the NPM project are now read-only and canâ€™t directly push the NPM package for safety reasons.
- We have internally rotated the secrets to publish on Ledgerâ€™s GitHub.
- Developers, please check again that youâ€™re using the latest version, 1.1.8.
- Ledger, along with @Walletconnect and our partners, have reported the bad actorâ€™s wallet address. The address is now visible on @chainalysis. @Tether_to has frozen the bad actorâ€™s USDT.
- We remind you to always Clear Sign with your Ledger. What you see on the Ledger screen is what you actually sign. If you still need to blind sign, use an additional Ledger mint wallet or parse your transaction manually.
- We are actively talking with customers whose funds might have been affected, and working proactively to help those individuals at this time.
- We are filing a complaint and working with law enforcement on the investigation to find the attacker.
- Weâ€™re studying the exploit in order to avoid further attacks. We believe the attackerâ€™s address where the funds were drained is here: 0x658729879fca881d9526480b82ae00efc54b5c2d

Thank you to @WalletConnect, @Tether_io, @Chainalysis, @zachxbt, and the whole community that helped us and continue to help us identify and solve this attack.

Ledger Library Exploit Explainer for Average Folks

What is going on with the recent alerts not to use dapps?

A library that is used by many dapps that is maintained by Ledger was compromised and a wallet drainer was added.

What do I do as a normal user?

Do not interact with any dapp front ends on websites for now. This is an ongoing situation and it is risky to use dapps currently if you don't understand what backend libraries they use.

How does this drain your money?

If you visit the website you won't get automatically drained or your funds. However, prompts from your browser wallet (like MM) will display that give your assets to the malicious actors.

Does Ledger know about this?

Yes they do and are working on it.

Note: Even after Ledger corrects the bad code in their library, projects using and deploying that library will need to update things before it is safe to use dapps that use Ledger's web3 libraries.

Disclaimer: This is my own opinion and not the opinion of any of my employers. Take this advice at your own risk.

Bitcoin ğŸ¤ Solana.

Probabilities can change very quickly. And so I think you should be prepared to change your mind often. 

But in school and most other places they don't emphasize this enough. As if it's some heroic act and higher moral ground sticking to your original thesis. 

But when you think about it, it's ridiculous to assume you'll get it right at the beginning stages of forming a thesis. You should be changing your mind more often than not as you do more work!

As I sit here today, likely biased by the price action, but processing months of more work I am adjusting my 20% probability that SOL flips ETH. That was Dec 1, 2023 when I came out with that prediction in the episode on @theempirepod. SOL was at $60.

That math assumed 20% * $250B ETH FDMC (on Dec 1) = $50B SOL FDMC = $88 / SOL

SOL is at $123 now.

At the time it felt right as I said it would happen this cycle (probabilities without timing are useless) but I now I don't see a reason why Solana can't be at parity with Ethereum and eventually overtake it.  Timing, as always, is tricky...

I'm updating my probability to 80% that Solana converges on Ethereum's market cap this cycle (within ~3 years). Why not 100%? 

Well because nothing is 100% but mindful that SOL is a younger network. Although things in tech and markets are not linear or slow once they start working. 

But also because I also think ETH's market cap expands during this time, and so aggregate flows in crypto may be a bottleneck. 

Although this also assumes rotation within crypto to be more SOL centric. But that is marginal. I think most of the outperformance of SOL and gap closing will be a higher share of new inflows going to SOL relative to other networks. But in crypto correlation is still high so higher SOL also likely means higher ETH and other assets (see price action of AVAX outperforming SOL in last few weeks FWIW)...

But enough with the rant. Uncle duties call so I need to go back to opening presents with little kids. Here's the TLDR and updated math:

I don't see a reason why Solana can't be at parity with Ethereum and eventually overtake it. But pegging probability of that happening this cycle at 80%:

80% * 275B ETH FDMC = $220B SOL FDMC = $400 / SOL 
 
* FDMC and price likely expand for both ETH and SOL, as inflows growth and overall crypto mkt cap grows (high correlation within crypto persists this cycle). So most important thing is the ratio of SOL/ETH and that converging so that FDMC = 1:1

Months of building, and now Rage v2 is finally in beta!

Weâ€™ve spent about 2 years building / iterating on perp products and all those learning have culminated in v2. I think this can be our mark on the onchain perp space. 
 
Ironically in late 2021 (when we got together) nobody wanted to use onchain perps. The bull market was in full force and CEX founders were still CTâ€™s main characters. 
 
But eventually CEXs fell from grace and with that onchain perps began to see some adoption. It started with @GMX_IO showing that you could build a big perp business with a bunch of ETH liquidity and a couple thousand traders. It turns out opening up 7/8 figure trades in a single transaction was great PMF. 
 
Around the same time, @GainsNetwork_io and @synthetix_io extended the oracle perps to more assets like forex and other top cryptos. And soon after that, @HyperliquidX + @aevoxyz brought on long tail assets using orderbooks on their custom AppChains.

Fast forward to today, onchain perps have clear PMF but are still < 2% the size of CEX perps. Imo there are a couple things holding us back:

- Many diff perps/L2s/Appchains
- Each avenue has its own listings
- Liquidity is fragmented
- UX doesnâ€™t rival CEXs

These are the problems we set out to solve with v2. In simple terms, we aggregate all perps across all chains in one place, give you best price/funding execution, handle bridging for you behind the scenes, and use account abstraction to make trading feel like a CEX. 
 
There is more, but Iâ€™ll save that for another tweet. In the meanwhile, join discord and get an invite to start trading!

When you invest:
Have entry & exit prices
Have base, downside, upside cases
Assign probabilities to those
These are not meant to be static
Update & stress test them w/ new information
If you don't do this, you'll get carried away

There's always opportunity costs
There's a point where it meaningfully changes your life
There's a point where you walk away 
But always preserve the ability to come back
Factor that in & optimize for independence & owning your time

The incentivized testnet will end in 2 hours. We are ready for your first mint on AvalancheğŸ”º at: 

â° 9AM UTC / 5PM CST / 4AM EST

Token: $NULL
Tokens per Ticket: 10,000 NULL

Ticket Total Supply: 10,000 - 60,000

Note: The total supply ranges from 10,000 to 60,000 tickets, as the number of tickets generated per block is random. However, if the randomness of tickets follows a normal distribution, the expected total should be around 30,000, with $NULL's overall amount being approximately 300,000,000.

Unique Innovations:

- FutureHash Lottery: Nullity uses the FutureHash protocol to utilize future block data for fully on-chain random number calculations, ensuring fairness and transparency.

- Lucky Ticket Feature: Any participant has the chance to achieve an amazing winning rate of up to 600%!

Fees:

50% AMM pool
30% buyback $NULL
10% future growth and marketing
10% infrastructure and team development

Key Characteristics of $NULL:

- 100% Fair Launch: Controlled entirely by the community, ensuring equitable distribution and ownership.

- Governance Role: Empowers holders to participate in crucial decision-making processes and the future direction of Nullity.

- Enhanced Luck Value for Future Minting: Increases the probability of favorable outcomes for token holders in future minting events.

- Consumption in Future Minting Processes: $NULL will be utilized in upcoming token creation events, integrating it deeply into the ecosystem.

- Buyback Initiatives: Periodic buybacks to regulate supply and add value to the token.

- Utility in Future Avalanche Subnets: $NULL is poised to be a significant utility token within upcoming Avalanche subnets, expanding its use cases and relevance.

ğŸª‚ The airdrop reward campaign for the incentivized testnet is still ongoing. Don't miss out on the final 2 hours to get a first-hand experience of Nullity's magic.

$NULL 

This invention surpasses $ZERO in greatness. It's easier to standardize, more equitable, and fully on-chain. Let me explain:

First, the draw's randomness comes from future block data, using the third block's hash and the fourth block's difficulty data for random number generation, with the draw occurring in the fifth block. Since no one can predict the data of future blocks yet to be produced, this ingeniously solves the problem of generating true randomness on-chain.

Another intriguing feature is the Lucky Ticket. Unlike $ZERO, the number of tickets per block isn't fixed at one, but varies between 1-6. A block can produce up to six tickets. So, if there's only one participant in the current block, they could sweep the entire prize pool. I prefer to call it the 'Explosive Block'."

It represents a genuinely viable approach to standardizing fair launch asset distribution, marking yet another remarkable social experiment.
